channel.title: julia on The Tarkus Factory
channel.description: Recent content in julia on The Tarkus Factory

item.title: Creating your own blog with Julia and Franklin
item.description: In this post, we are going to discuss how to build your own blog with Julia and Franklin.jl, a popular static site generator among Julia users who create their own blogs or even build websites for tutorials. I hope that if you are reading this entry and you don’t have your own space, it can motivate you to build your own website. Some Reasons to Create Your Own Blog Blogs may sound old-fashioned, something created by people who are still living in the 90s, typing with passion about the political system while listening to Soundgarden in the background and drinking some kind of cheap beer… or programmers.

item.title: set up NeoVim + Tmux for a Data Science Workflow with Julia
item.description: In this post, I will provide some notes on getting started with Neovim for a Data Science Workflow. This setup is not strictly related to Julia and can also be used with Python and R. The idea is to work with a double panel structure, where one side contains your code and the other side has the REPL, which receives the snippets of code you send from the code side.

item.title: Using evotrees.jl for time series prediction
item.description: Introduction In this post, I want to show an analysis of a time series that I’ve been working on. Usually, when dealing with time series, it is not so common to use machine learning algorithms (without at least trying more traditional models like the ARIMA family), but I still wanted to test how well a GBM model fits for these kinds of problems that are so popular. NOTE: I don’t recommend starting with models of this type for time series problems.

item.title: World Happiness Report - EDA & clustering with Julia
item.description: The purpose of this post is to show Julia as a language for data analysis and Machine Learning. Sadly Kaggle does not support Julia Kernels (hopefully, they will add it in the future). Therefore I wanted to take advantage of this space to show a reimplementation of Python/R Notebooks to Julia. In this context, I took data on happiness in countries in 2021 and some factors considered in this exciting survey.
